workshop.name: In-class problem: inelastic collision
workshop.intro: This will be our first attempt at working a problem in class in groups.  The problem has been designed to be quick to do, and straightforward to mark since you will be marking it.
workshop.instructauthors:
Objectives

  1. Students will write down knows and unknowns for a collision.
  2. Students will solve for unknowns using conservation of momentum and the definition of coefficient of restitution.

As shown in the diagram, in a test of materials strength, a 50 g ball bearing collides with a 1.2 kg steel plate. The ball bearing was going at 30 m/s to the right before the collision and the steel plate was stationary. The steel plate had been held stationary until just before the collision, but it was released milliseconds before the ball bearing hits it so that the collision is very nearly isolated. The coefficient of restitution for the collision is 0.80. Use the axes defined in the diagram.

a) Define variables and in terms of your defined variables obtain an expression for the x-component of velocity of the ball bearing just after the collision. Note: you do not have to find the velocity of the plate.

b) Find the numerical value of the x-component of velocity of the ball bearing after the collision.
workshop.instructreviewers: You will assess several (probably two) submissions by other people.  Follow the marking  guide.  The marking guide should be detailed enough that you won't have to use much judgement.
workshop.conclusion: Thanks for participating in this activity.  Note that you will have received two marks.  One mark will be for your submission.  The other mark is for the quality of feedback you gave to the submissions you were asked to assess.  The grade for the quality of assessment is found by comparing your assessment with the assessments of others who marked the same submission.  If you all agree on the grade then you get a perfect mark for your assessment.

workshopform_accumulative_dimension.description:
They should have started by writing down the knowns and unknowns, defining symbols as they do so.  What symbols they have chosen is unimportant as long as they are clear.  What they shouldn't have done is just use one symbol (like m), for the inertias of both objects.  They need a different symbol for each inertia and different symbols for initial and final velocities of both objects.  They also need to use consistent units.  Here's how I would do it:

mb = 0.050 kg    (ball)

mP = 1.2 kg       (plate)

vbix = 30 m/s    

vPix = 0            (They might not even bother to write this down.  That's fine.)

vbfx = ?

vPfx = ?

e = 0.80     (Coefficient of restitution.  They might not have bothered to write this down.  That's OK.)

Define clear symbols - 1 mark

Didn't clearly define symbols - 0 marks

They need to write down a conservation  of momentum equation.  Again, don't be picky about the symbols, as long as they stick with the symbols they defined earlier.  If they didn't clearly define symbols, but at this point write what appears to be a correct equation, then they should get part marks.

In terms of my symbols the equation would be

\( m_b v_{bix} + m_P v_{Pix} = m_b v_{bfx} + m_P v_{Pfx} \)

but  since \(v_{2ix} = 0 \) they might have gone straight to writing it down as

\( m_b v_{bix} = m_b v_{bfx} + m_P v_{Pfx} \)

which is absolutely fine.

Correct equation, written in terms of symbols defined earlier - 2 marks

Correct equation (or equation which appears correct  giving  benefit of doubt), but either consistent symbols were not used, or they had not defined their symbols earlier - 1 mark

No equation, or incorrect  equation, or choice of symbols is so unclear that you can't tell whether the equation is correct - 0 marks

They need to have used the definition of the coefficient of restitution to get a second equation.  There are several ways they may have written this, such as

\( v_{Pfx} - v_{bfx} = -e (v_{Pix} - v_{bix}) \)

or perhaps

\( e = - \frac{v_{Pfx} - v_{bfx}}{v_{Pix} - v_{bix}} \) 

All of  the parts involving \( v_{Pix} \) could have just been left out entirely since it is zero.  If  they have done that then that is perfectly fine.

Wrote a correct equation relating initial x-comp. of relative velocity to final, using coefficient of restitution - 2 marks

Attempt to relate velocities with coefficient of restitution, but equation incorrect - 1 mark

No attempt to relate velocities with coefficient of restitution - 0 marks

They now need to (symbolically) solve for the unknown final velocity component of the ball.  They should get something similar to

\( v_{bfx} = \frac{m_b v_{bix} - e m_P v_{bix}}{m_b + m_P} \)

or

\( v_{bfx} = \frac{m_b - em_P}{m_b + m_P}v_{bix} \)

Equation correctly solved for vbfx - 1 mark

Algebraic errors lead to wrong expression, or did not solve symbolically before putting in values - 0 marks

Now we can plug in the numbers and enter the expression into  our calculator.  They don't really need to have shown much for this process.  If they got the correct expression then they might have been comfortable enough to just enter it all into their calculator without writing  it down.  That's fine.  Also, it doesn't matter whether they worked in kg or g, as long as they were consistent working in one or the other.  Entering in the values, I get

\( v_{bfx} = \frac{(0.05 \, \textrm{kg})(30 \, \textrm{m/s}) - 0.8 (1.2 \, \textrm{kg})(30 \, \textrm{m/s})}{1.25 kg} \)

= -21.8 m/s

Note that the negative sign is important!  It indicates that the ball "recoils" and moves in the opposite direction from the way it was originally going.  

Correct answer (including negative  sign) - 1 mark

Incorrect answer - 0 marks
